## Natural history notes

The Knotted Spikerush (Eleocharis interstincta) is a robust perennial sedge native to the southeastern U.S. It typically grows in marshes, ditches, swamps, and shallow wetlands, forming dense clumps up to 1.5 m tall. The stems are cylindrical, hollow, and jointed, with distinct swollen “nodes” (interstices), giving rise to its common name. Dense stands help stabilize soils in wetlands and provide cover for fish, amphibians, and invertebrates.
